Literature Review: The advent of CRISPR-Cas technology has revolutionized the field of functional genomics, enabling researchers to conduct large-scale genetic screens with unprecedented precision and efficiency. This literature review focuses on the emerging field of pooled genome-scale CRISPR screens in single cells, a powerful approach that combines the high-throughput capabilities of CRISPR with the resolution of single-cell analysis.CRISPR-Cas systems have rapidly become the tool of choice for genetic perturbations due to their simplicity, versatility, and effectiveness. Shalem et al. (2014) demonstrated the feasibility of genome-wide CRISPR screens in mammalian cells, paving the way for numerous applications in functional genomics. However, traditional pooled CRISPR screens typically rely on bulk readouts, which can mask the heterogeneity of cellular responses and limit the detection of complex phenotypes.The integration of single-cell technologies with CRISPR screens has addressed these limitations, allowing researchers to interrogate gene function at unprecedented resolution. Dixit et al. (2016) pioneered the combination of CRISPR screening with single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), introducing the Perturb-seq method. This approach enables the simultaneous measurement of gene expression profiles and CRISPR-induced perturbations in individual cells, providing a wealth of information about gene function and cellular states.Building upon this concept, Adamson et al. (2016) developed CROP-seq, another method for coupling CRISPR screening with scRNA-seq. These techniques have opened up new avenues for exploring gene function and regulatory networks in various biological contexts. For instance, Datlinger et al. (2017) applied CROP-seq to study T cell receptor signaling, demonstrating the power of this approach in immunology research.While scRNA-seq-based readouts offer comprehensive transcriptomic information, other single-cell phenotyping methods have also been integrated with CRISPR screens. Feldman et al. (2019) developed a method combining CRISPR screening with high-content imaging and machine learning, enabling the analysis of complex cellular phenotypes at scale. This approach has proven particularly valuable for studying cellular processes that are difficult to capture with transcriptomic readouts alone.The success of pooled single-cell CRISPR screens relies heavily on efficient delivery of CRISPR components and accurate matching of perturbations to individual cells. Replogle et al. (2020) introduced CRISPR-sciATAC, a method that combines single-cell CRISPR screening with assay for transposase-accessible chromatin sequencing (ATAC-seq), providing insights into the epigenetic consequences of genetic perturbations.Data analysis presents a significant challenge in single-cell CRISPR screens due to the high-dimensional nature of the data and the need to account for technical variability. Datlinger et al. (2021) developed a computational framework specifically designed for analyzing single-cell CRISPR screen data, addressing issues such as batch effects and dropout events.The application of pooled single-cell CRISPR screens has yielded important insights across various fields of biology. For example, Jaitin et al. (2016) used this approach to dissect the regulatory circuitry of innate immunity, uncovering novel regulators of the immune response. In cancer research, Norman et al. (2019) employed single-cell CRISPR screens to identify genes involved in cancer immunotherapy resistance, highlighting the potential of this technology in developing new therapeutic strategies.As the field continues to evolve, new developments are expanding the capabilities of single-cell CRISPR screens. Rubin et al. (2019) introduced CRISPR-sciATAC, a method that enables simultaneous perturbation and profiling of chromatin accessibility in single cells, providing a powerful tool for studying gene regulatory networks.In conclusion, pooled genome-scale CRISPR screens in single cells represent a transformative approach in functional genomics. By combining the power of CRISPR-mediated perturbations with the resolution of single-cell analysis, researchers can now explore gene function and cellular heterogeneity at unprecedented scales and depth. As the technology continues to mature and new analytical tools are developed, we can expect this approach to drive significant advances in our understanding of cellular biology and disease mechanisms, ultimately contributing to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.
